Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XIV. THE TILLE THEKERS. The Journey to Bethlehem; the birth of Jesus. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor

[Scene I] Bethlehem, a cattle shed. 1. Jos. All weldand God in Trinite, I praye Ã¾e, lord, for thy grete myght, Vnto thy symple seruand see, Here in Ã¾is place wher we are pight, oure self allone; Lord, graunte vs gode herberow Ã¾is nyght within Ã¾is wone. 2. For we haue sought both vppe and doune, Thurgh diuerse stretis in Ã¾is cite, So mekill pepull is comen to towne, Ãat we can nowhare herbered be, Ã¾er is slike prees; For suthe I can no socoure see, but belde vs with Ã¾ere bestes. 3. And yf we here all nyght abide, We shall be stormed in Ã¾is steede; Ãe walles are doune on ilke a side, Ãe ruffe is rayned aboven oure hede, als haue I roo, Say, Marie doughtir, what is thy rede? How sall we doo? 4. For in grete nede nowe are we stedde, As Ã¾ou thy selffe the soth may see, For here is nowthir cloth ne bedde, And we are weyke and all werie, and fayne wolde rest. Now, gracious god, for thy mercie! wisse vs Ã¾e best. 5. Mar. God will vs wisse, full wele witt ?e, Ãer-fore, Joseph, be of gud chere, For in Ã¾is place borne will he be Ãat sall vs saue fro sorowes sere, boÃ¾e even and morne. Sir, witte ?e wele Ã¾e tyme is nere, hee will be borne. 6. Jos. Ãan behoves vs bide here stille, Here in Ã¾is same place all Ã¾is nyght. Mar. ?a, sir, forsuth it is Goddis will. Jos. Ãan wolde I fayne we had sum light, what so befall. It waxis right myrke vnto my sight, and colde withall. 7. I will go gete vs light for-thy, And fewell fande with me to bryng. [Goes out. Mar. All weldand God yow gouerne and gy, As he is sufferayne of all thyng fo[r] his grete myght, And lende me grace to his louyng Ãat I me dight. 8. Nowe in my sawle grete ioie haue I, I am all cladde in comforte clere, Now will be borne of my body Both God and man to-gedir in feere. Blist mott he be! Jesu! my son Ã¾at is so dere, nowe borne is he. [Mary worships the child. 9. Hayle my lord God! hayle prince of pees! Hayle my fadir, and hayle my sone! Hayle souereyne sege all synnes to sesse! Hayle God and man in erth to wonne! Hayle! thurgh whos myht All Ã¾is worlde was first be-gonne, merknes and light. 10. Sone, as I am sympill sugett of thyne, Vowchesaffe, swete sone I pray Ã¾e, That I myght Ã¾e take in Ã¾e[r] armys of myne, And in Ã¾is poure wede to arraie Ã¾e; Graunte me Ã¾i blisse! As I am thy modir chosen to be in sothfastnesse.

[Scene II] Joseph outside the shed. 11. Jos. A! lorde, what the wedir is colde! Ãe fellest freese Ã¾at euere I felyd, I pray God helpe Ã¾am Ã¾at is alde, And namely Ã¾am Ã¾at is vnwelde, so may I saie. Now, gud God Ã¾ou be my belde, as Ã¾ou best may. [A sudden light shines. 12. A! lord God! what light is Ã¾is Ãat comes shynyng Ã¾us sodenly? I can not saie, als haue I blisse; When I come home vn-to Marie Ã¾an sall I spirre. A! here be god, for nowe come I. [Re-enters the shed.

[Scene III] interior of the shed, as before. Mar. ?e ar welcum sirre. 13. Jos. Say, Marie doghtir, what chere with Ã¾e? Mar. Right goode, Joseph, as has been ay. Jos. O Marie! what swete thyng is Ã¾at on thy kne? Mar. It is my sone, Ã¾e soth to saye, Ã¾at is so gud. Jos. Wele is me I bade Ã¾is day to se Ã¾is foode! 14. Me merueles mekill of Ã¾is light Ãat Ã¾us-gates shynes in Ã¾is place, For suth it is a selcouth sight! Mar. Ãis hase he ordand of his grace, my sone so ?ing, A starne to be schynyng a space at his bering. 15. For Balam tolde ful longe be-forne How Ã¾at a sterne shulde rise full hye, And of a maiden shulde be borne A sonne Ã¾at sall oure saffyng be fro caris kene. For suth it is my sone so free, be whame Balam gon meene. 16. Jos. Nowe welcome, floure fairest of hewe, I shall Ã¾e menske with mayne and myght. Hayle! my maker, hayle Crist Jesu! Hayle, riall kyng, roote of all right! Hayle! saueour. Hayle, my lorde, lemer of light, Hayle, blessid floure! 17. Mar. Nowe lord! Ã¾at all Ã¾is worlde schall wynne, To Ã¾e my sone is Ã¾at I saye, Here is no bedde to laye the inne, Ãerfore my dere sone, I Ã¾e praye sen it is soo, Here in Ã¾is cribbe I myght Ã¾e lay betwene Ã¾er bestis two. 18. And I sall happe Ã¾e, myn owne dere childe, With such clothes as we haue here. Jos. O Marie! beholde Ã¾es beestis mylde, They make louyng in ther manere as Ã¾ei wer men. For-sothe it semes wele be ther chere Ã¾are lord Ã¾ei ken. 19. Mar. Ther lorde Ã¾ai kenne, Ã¾at wate I wele, They worshippe hym with myght and mayne; The wedir is colde, as ye may feele, To halde hym warme Ã¾ei are full fayne with Ã¾are warme breth, And oondis on hym, is noght to layne, to warm hym with. 20. O! nowe slepis my sone, blist mot he be, And lyes full warme Ã¾er bestis by-twene. Jos. O nowe is fulfilled, for-suth I see, Ãat Abacuc in mynde gon mene and preched by prophicie. He saide oure sauyoure shall be sene betwene bestis lye; 21. And nowe I see Ã¾e same in sight. Mar. ?a! sir, for-suth Ã¾e same is he. Jos. Honnoure and worshippe both day and nyght Ay-lastand lorde, be done to Ã¾e, all way as is worthy, And, lord, to thy seruice I oblissh me, with all myn herte holy. 22. Mar. Ãou mercyfull maker, most myghty, My God, my lorde, my sone so free, Thy hande-mayden for soth am I, And to thi seruice I oblissh me, with all myn herte entere. Thy blissing, beseke I thee, Ã¾ou graunte vs all in feere.
